page.title: 03Landscape of Thundersley.
page.content: Unlike South Benfleet, Thundersley is situated on a plateau. From the hill on which the ancient church of St Peter stands, there are magnificent views across the Essex countryside, from the Thames to the Crouch. The old London road,now the A.13,runs through Thundersley to Southend and gives the district easy access to neighbouring areas. Light industries took up places along this route and small clothing factories, outposts of the East London "Rag-trade",can still be found here. Although much of the area has been taken up by private housing and small housing estates,remnants of the old royal forests still exist:Coombe Wood and Thundersley Glen which were once part of a royal manor. The lodge belonging to King John has, alas,been demolished,but the connection survives through a local comprehensive school.
